settings.title: The best exfoliators for oily skin + acne
settings.desc:
Alpha & Beta Hydroxy Acids

For those with oily skin, Dr. Mehr recommends using chemical exfoliators that contain beta-hydroxy acid. Here’s why: “The issue with excess oil is that it causes the top layer of the skin cells to stick together,” she says, adding that this can clog pores and lead to cystic acne and acne scarring. “Beta-hydroxy acids such as salicylic acid are great at dissolving the oil between the skin cells.” 

Gentle Physical Exfoliators

Physical exfoliators, such as jojoba beads, can also help reduce oil production and the clumping of dead skills in oily and acne-prone skin, in turn helping prevent breakouts, Dr. Mack says. Bonus points if you find a physical exfoliator that is also a chemical exfoliator. 

In-Office Chemical Peels

Chemical peels are another form of exfoliation that Dr. Mack suggests specifically for people with extremely oily and breakout-prone skin. However, she advises avoiding at-home chemical peels as they can damage the skin. “I recommend an in-office chemical peel with 30% salicylic acid performed by a board-certified dermatologist,” she says. “Beta-hydroxy acids like salicylic acid more easily penetrate pores, helping to remove debris and oil.”

settings.quotes: “Oilier skin types are also usually more acne-prone because of the congestion created by clogged pores and cellular debris…”

settings.title: Takeaway: Exfoliate 3-4 Times Per Week
settings.text_center:
Since people with acne skin deal with excessive oil production, Dr. Mehr notes it’s important to increase the amount of exfoliation. This, she says, “prevents excessive oil from causing the top layer of skin cells — or epidermis — from sticking together, clogging the pores, and leading to cystic acne and acne scarring.”

For oily skin, Dr. Mack prescribes exfoliating up to three times per week. If your skin is oily and acne-prone, she suggests upping it to four times per week. And, if your skin responds well to the exfoliation, meaning there’s no sign of irritation, Dr. Mehr says it’s safe to exfoliate as often as once to twice daily. However, if you’re new to exfoliation, remember to start off slow and increase the frequency gradually as your skin tolerates it. 

Signs that you may be over-exfoliating, Dr. Mack and Dr. Mehr say include having pink, dry, tight, or irritated skin or even eczema-like rashes. If you’re not exfoliating enough, Dr. Mehr says your skin may appear dull and clogged, so upping the frequency of exfoliation is a good idea.

As for where exfoliation fits into your skincare routine, Dr. Mack recommends cleansing your skin first to remove all the debris, makeup, and oil, which then allows the exfoliator to more effectively remove the dead skin cells. Then, Dr. Mehr says you can apply your topicals like serums and creams which can better penetrate the skin once the dead skin is out of the way.
